messageBody:
On 1/22/06, Antti Karanta <Antti.Karanta@...> wrote:
>

> http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm#tests_18
>
> So, I made tearDown set reference to anything instantiated in setUp to
> null and the problem was gone.


It's useful in other scenarios as well, such as running tests in the same
JVM in sequence (either because you are using ant in fork="no" mode or you
are distributing your tests on client JVM's that you want to keep running
between tests).

Bottom line: always use setUp() and tearDown() to initialize and unitialize
your tests. Don't rely on field initialization:

Bad:

private Account m_account = new Account();

Good:

private int m_count = null; // whatever

public void setUp() {
m_count = new Account();
}

public void tearDown() {
m_count = null;
}

--
Cédric
